Def.Name: Black Maple
Def.Description: Large tree, 40' - 70' tall, broad, round or oval crown; trunk up to 36" diameter. Black maple is now acknowledged to be an ecotype of the sugar maple.
Def.Leaves: Simple, opposite leaves are a rich, deep green color above with entire wavy margins. Leaves are usually three-lobed but are occasionally five-lobed and are 4" — 5 1/2" long and wide. Foliage is dull green above and pale, yellowish-green below. When mature, the leaves have a drooping appearance. The stem of the leaf is enlarged at the base and surrounded by a winged appendage called a stipule. Fall foliage color is yellow.
Def.Twigs: Lenticels (Dots) on twigs are large and warty. Year-old twigs are light brown with stipular scars that nearly encircle the twig.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Samara with wings that are nearly parallel. The fruit matures in September.
Def.Bark: The mature bark of the older specimens is deeply furrowed and much darker than the common sugar maple.
Def.Range: More commonly found along streams and broad flood plains, not on the uplands where sugar maple is more common.
Def.Remarks: Black maple is now acknowledged to be an ecotype of the sugar maple. Flowers are yellowish-green and bloom in April prior to the emergence of the foliage. Commercially, the lumber has the same uses as the sugar maple, and the tree is also a source of maple syrup.
